channel.title: Comments on: Vector field from function

item.title: By: wlodek
item.dc:creator: wlodek
item.description:
hi,
Thanks for the example, but it's a bit non-physical. Electric field's magnitude should obviously be visualized with enorm(x,y), not by the potential. For some reason I cannot make these "palettes" work in the correct case - I just don't understand how colors in a palette react to these or those values of the plotted function. Back to RTFM :)
item.content:encoded:
hi,

Thanks for the example, but it’s a bit non-physical. Electric field’s magnitude should obviously be visualized with enorm(x,y), not by the potential. For some reason I cannot make these “palettes” work in the correct case – I just don’t understand how colors in a palette react to these or those values of the plotted function. Back to RTFM :)

item.title: By: hagen
item.dc:creator: hagen
item.description:
Hi Juan,
it depends on what directly you mean with a .dat file. If it is a text file with four columns conatining the needed information you could do something like <code>plot 'data.dat' u 1:2:3:4:(v($1,$2)) with vectors head size 0.08,20,60 filled lc palette</code>. If the text files contains the positions of the vectors and their directions, you might have a look at ./../../vector-field-from-data-file//index.html
item.content:encoded:
Hi Juan,

it depends on what directly you mean with a .dat file. If it is a text file with four columns conatining the needed information you could do something like plot 'data.dat' u 1:2:3:4:(v($1,$2)) with vectors head size 0.08,20,60 filled lc palette.
If the text files contains the positions of the vectors and their directions, you might have a look at ./../../vector-field-from-data-file/index.html

item.title: By: Juan
item.dc:creator: Juan
item.description: Very useful. How can I make it so it reads the 4 columns directly from a .dat file?
item.content:encoded: Very useful. How can I make it so it reads the 4 columns directly from a .dat file?

item.title: By: sergio
item.dc:creator: sergio
item.description: the script is very simple and complete very useful for my homework thank you very much!!
item.content:encoded:
the script is very simple and complete
very useful for my homework
thank you very much!!

item.title: By: hagen
item.dc:creator: hagen
item.description: I'm afraid that there is no possibility to get transparent arrows directly in gnuplot. What can be set to transparency is the fillstyle, which is possible for some of the plotting styles. For example have a look at <a href="./../../manpage-gnuplot-4-6/index.html#Q1-1-131" class="manpage" rel="nofollow">circles</a>
item.content:encoded: I’m afraid that there is no possibility to get transparent arrows directly in gnuplot. What can be set to transparency is the fillstyle, which is possible for some of the plotting styles. For example have a look at circles

item.title: By: alaladfel
item.dc:creator: alaladfel
item.description:
Perfect !
I have a question though, in the case where the background is transparent the white arrows may be visible, even if they're linked to a low magnitude. Is there a way to define a palette with transparent value ?
item.content:encoded:
Perfect !

I have a question though, in the case where the background is transparent the white arrows may be visible, even if they’re linked to a low magnitude.
Is there a way to define a palette with transparent value ?
